I have never like the term "inertia". It is confusing and unnecessary. For non-rotational situations mass is a much clearer idea than "inertia". It has units and, as noted in Newton's Laws, it can explain why more and more force is needed for larger and larger masses to experience change in their motion. No need for vague "tendencies" due to a term that has no way of measuring, and no units. Mass can be used much more clearly to explain all those "inertia" situations.

In this clip the discussion is about Moment of Inertia, which DOES have meaning, and units to measure it. By calling them both "inertia" this is sloppy - rare for Veritasium. :-)

Wouldn't this also have something to do with rigid and non-rigid bodies? The reason I say that is because in both cases you have some amount of mass with some inertia. In the raw egg, the yoke keeps moving because it has inertia and also because it is not bound to the egg from the inside, it's more fluid, whereas in the hard egg there still is inertia, but since you spent energy trying to stop the egg at its center, that energy was transferred to the portions bound to the skin from the inside too.

Conclusion: Inertia alone doesn't seem to explain the simple observation of one egg stopping and one egg rotating still, since they both have inertia.

While it is inertia, what can be more appreciated is the actual definition of how the yolk is able to stay spinning due to its fluidity compared to that of the cooked egg which is in a sort of rigid state.

Same thing as using the brakes in your car. When you brake, the car stops but you feel yourself carrying on forward. Seat belts stop you for flying out the windscreen.

Only fresh eggs will start spinning again. There is a supporting membrane that holds the yolk in place inside the egg. As egg starts to go bad, this membrane breaks down. So when you stop the egg spinning, even though the yolk continues to spin inside, there's no efficient way for it to pass this energy back to the shell, and the egg won't start spinning again. Good way to test if your eggs are good before cracking them in the fry pan :)

No, he's not saying that - it's simply because the friction on the inside of the egg shell isn't enough to make the liquid stop when the shell stops. So when you stop the shell, the liquid keeps spinning - and when you let go, the spinning of the liquid causes the shell to start spinning too.

Momentum is a force based on mass and acceleration with formula Force=Mass*Acceleration, Inertia is the tendency for that force to remain the same. 
Drop something on your foot from knee level. Now drop the same object from hip level and head level. The increase in that force (momentum) is because the object is moving faster. It also changes with mass.

Inertia allows (causes really) momentum. The momentum of an object is it's mass multiplied by it's acceleration. It's the amount of (counter)force required to bring a moving object to a halt. Think truck vs. car. If they are on a collision course, the truck has more mass thus more momentum and gets slowed down by the car. The car reverses course, and both carry on at a lesser velocity (determined by the difference between their masses). Force = Mass*Accleration

Without any force acting on it (friction is a force as well), it would go on forever. Just moving along a trajectory does not increase the energy of the object, thus it does not use any energy to do so. Different story would be if something moved away all the time from a gravitational force with constant speed, then it would have force and energy applied (since it gains potential energy).

Momentum is velocity*mass, and inertia is just a quality that is directly related to an object's mass. The higher an object's mass, the higher its inertia, i.e. the more force it takes to accelerate said object a specific amount. I think this experiment is a better demonstration of momentum than inertia though, as what you see is the conservation of momentum of the yolk despite the momentum of the eggshell being put to 0.

I have been looking for a way to find out if an egg is boiled or not from outside and without then having to eat it because I broke it etc. for years(!) and now I've found this. I feel complete.
is this how gyroscopes work?

The point is, when you stop the hard boiled egg, you stop everything, including the inside because it's solid.  When you stop the raw egg, you're only stopping the shell and the inside keeps spinning.  That's why when you let go of the raw egg, the spinning inside (due to friction with the shell) causes it to start spinning again - because you never stopped the inside.
eggcellent eggsperiment

But what about the pressure on the egg that forces the egg to stop? 
secondly, all objects have inertia as well as the hard egg?

I meant for example if you take an egg out of the fridge and you don't know whether it's boiled or not, you can do this trick to check it. Of course you can't use it to see if an egg was boiled too long, it doesn't get harder inside once it's hard already. Almost the same thing for soft boiled eggs: It's only a small part in the middle which is fluid (if even), which doesn't have a big effect.

doesn't work so well to tell if the egg is hard or soft boiled, that is why so often people way over boil an egg, whether they want soft or hard boiled. and yes you can over boil a hard boiled egg. you want the yolk to be a nice yellow all the way through, it starts to get a green tinge when it is over boiled, easiest to see on the outside of the yolk. and of course for a soft boiled egg you want the yolk to still be creamy. the thing that sucks about an over boiled egg is the yolk is dry.
The answer is always inertia!
